findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract updates the excluded from Fee and Swap status of an account even if its current state is the same as the one passed as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: AFI - Accumulated Fees Inconsistency
findings.description: The contract resets the accumulated fees variables without performing a distribution of the accumulated rewards, creating an inconsistency between the actual accumulated tokens from the fees.

findings.title: MVN - Misleading Variables Naming
findings.description: Variables can have misleading names if their names do not accurately reflect the value they contain or the purpose they serve.

findings.title: CR - Code Repetition
findings.description: The contract contains repetitive code segments which can lead to issues like gas efficiency, complexity, readability, security, and maintainability of the source code.

findings.title: MAP - Misleading Admin Permission
findings.description: The contract has a variable named `owner` that is initialized to zero address, creating ambiguity regarding the ownership structure.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` declaration can save gas when it is defined.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L18 - Multiple Pragma Directives
findings.description: If the contract includes multiple conflicting pragma directives, it may produce unexpected errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
